chunks.text: So let's start by talking at a high level, what

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: does a computer do?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So fundamentally, it does two things.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: One, performs calculations.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It performs a lot of calculations.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Computers these days are really, really fast.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: A billion calculations per second is probably not far off.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It performs these calculations, and it has to store them

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: somewhere, right?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Stores them in computer memory.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So a computer also has to remember results.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And these days, it's not uncommon to find computers

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with hundreds of gigabytes of storage.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the kinds of calculations that computers do,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: there are two kinds.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So one are calculations that are built into the language.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: These are the very low level types of calculations,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: things like addition, subtraction, multiplication,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And once you have a language that

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: has these sort of primitive calculation types,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you as a programmer can put these types together

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and then define your own calculations.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then you create new types of calculations,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and the computer will be able to perform those as well.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I think one thing I want to stress,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and we're going to come back to this again

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: during this entire lecture, actually,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is computers only know what you tell them.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Computers only do what you tell them to do.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: They're not magical.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: They don't have a mind.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: They just know how to perform calculations really,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: really quickly.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So there were parts where we made decisions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Are we close enough?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: There were parts where we repeated some steps.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So at the end, we said repeat steps one, two, three.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's the flow of control.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the last part of the recipe was a way to stop.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You don't want a program that keeps going and going.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Or for a recipe, you don't want to keep baking bread forever.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You want to stop at some point.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: 10 breads is enough.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you have to have a way of stopping.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In the previous example, the way of stopping

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: was that we decided we were close enough.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Close enough was maybe being within 0.01, 0.0001,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: whatever you pick.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this recipe is, therefore, an algorithm.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In computer science speak, it's going to be an algorithm.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that's what we're going to learn about in this class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we're dealing with computers.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we actually want to capture a recipe inside a computer,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: a computer being a mechanical process.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And historically, there were two ways of,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: historically, there were two different types of computers.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So originally, there were these things

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: called six-program computers.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I'm old enough to have used something

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: like this, where there's just numbers and plus,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: minus, multiplication, divide, and equal.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But calculators these days are a lot more complicated.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But way back then, an example of a fixed-program computer

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is this calculator.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It only knows how to do addition, multiplication,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: subtraction, division.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If you want to plot something, you can't.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If you want to go on the internet, set email with it,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you can't.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It can only do this one thing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And if you wanted to create a machine that did another thing,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: then you'd have to create another fixed-program computer

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that did a completely separate task.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's not very great.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's when stored-program computers came into play.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And these were machines that could

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: store a sequence of instructions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And these machines could execute the sequence

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of instructions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you could change the sequence of instructions

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and execute this different sequence of instructions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you could do different tasks in the same machine.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that's the computer as we know it these days.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the central processing unit is

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: where all of these decisions get made.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And these are all the peripherals.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the basic machine architecture.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So at the heart of every computer,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: there's just this basic architecture.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it contains, I guess, four main parts.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the first is the memory.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Input and output is the other one.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The ALU is where all of the operations are done.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the operations that the ALU can do

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are these really primitive operations, subtraction,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So what the memory contains is a bunch of data

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and your sequence of instructions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So interacting with the arithmetic logic unit

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is the control unit.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the control unit contains one program counter.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So when you load a sequence of instructions,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the program counter starts at the first sequence.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It gets what the first starts at the sequence,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: at the first instruction.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It gets what the instruction is, and it sends it to the ALU.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The ALU asks, what are we doing operations on here?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What's happening?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it might get some data.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If you're adding two numbers, it might get

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: two numbers from memory.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It might do some operations, and it might store data back

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: into memory.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And after it's done, the ALU is going to go back,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and the program counter is going to increase by one, which

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: means that we're going to go to the next sequence

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in the instruction set.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it just goes linearly instruction by instruction.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: There might be one particular instruction

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that does some sort of test.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's going to say, is this particular value greater

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or equal to or the same as this other particular value?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's a test, an example of a test.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the test is going to either return true or false.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And depending on the result of that test,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you might either go to the next instruction,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or you might set the program counter

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to go all the way back to the beginning

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you're not just sort of linearly stepping

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: through all the instructions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: There might be some control flow involved,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: where you might skip an instruction

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or start from the beginning or so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And after you're done, when you finished

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: executing the last instruction, then you

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: might output something.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's really the basic way that a computer works.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So just to recap, you have the stored program computer

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that contains these sequences of instructions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The primitive operations that it can do

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are addition, subtraction, logic operations, tests,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which are something equal to something else, something

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: less than and so on, and moving data,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: so storing data, moving data around, and things like that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the interpreter goes through every instruction

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and decides whether you're going to go to the next instruction,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: skip instructions, or repeat instructions, and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we talked about primitives.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And in fact, Alan Turing was a really great computer

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: scientist.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: He showed that you can compute anything

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: using the six primitives.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the six primitives are move left, move right, read right,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: scan, and do nothing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So using those six instructions and a piece of tape,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: he showed that you can compute anything.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And using those six instructions,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: programming languages came about that

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: created a more convenient set of primitives.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you don't have to program in only these six commands.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And one interesting thing, or one really important thing,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that came about from these six primitives

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is that if you can compute something in Python,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: let's say, if you write a program that

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: computes something in Python, then in theory,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you can write a program that computes the exact same thing

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in any other language.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that's a really powerful statement.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Think about that today when you review your slides.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Think about that again.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that's really powerful.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So once you have your set of primitives,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you can set of primitives for a particular language,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you can start creating expressions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And these expressions are going to be combinations

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of the primitives in the programming language.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the expressions are going to have some value.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And they're going to have some meaning

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in the programming language.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So let's do a little bit of a parallel with English,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: just so you see what I mean.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in English, the primitive constructs

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are going to be words.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: There's a lot of words in the English language.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Programming languages in Python, there are primitives,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: but there aren't as many of them.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So there are floats, booleans, these are numbers, strings,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and simple operators like addition, subtraction,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we have primitive constructs.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Using these primitive constructs,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we can start creating, in English, phrases, sentences.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the same in programming languages.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in English, we can say something like, cat dog boy.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That, we say, is not syntactically valid.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's bad syntax.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's noun, noun, noun.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That doesn't make sense.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What does have good syntax in English is noun, verb, noun.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So cat hugs boy is syntactically valid.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Similarly, in a programming language, something like this,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in Python in this case, a word and then the number five

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: doesn't really make sense.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's not syntactically valid.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But something like operator, operand, operator is OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So once you've created these phrases or these expressions

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that are syntactically valid, you

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: have to think about the static semantics of your phrase,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of your expression.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So for example, in English, I are hungry is good syntax.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But it's kind of weird to say.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We have a pronoun, a verb, and an adjective,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which doesn't really make sense.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I am hungry is better.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this does not have good static semantics.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Similarly, in programming languages,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and you'll get the hang of this the more you do it,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: something like this, 3.2 times 5 is OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But what does it mean?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What's the meaning to have a word added to a number?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: There's no meaning behind that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Syntax is OK because you have operator, operand, operator.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But it doesn't really make sense to add a number to a word,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: for example.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So once you have created these expressions that

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are syntactically correct and static semantically correct,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in English, for example, you think about the semantics.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So what's the meaning of the phrase?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And in English, you can actually have more than one meaning

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to an entire phrase.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in this case, flying planes are dangerous,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or flying planes can be dangerous,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: can have two meanings, is the act of flying a plane is dangerous,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or the plane that is in the air is dangerous.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this might be a cuter example.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This reading lamp hasn't uttered a word since I bought it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What's going on?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that has two meanings.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's playing on the word reading lamp.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In programming, so that's in English.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In English, you can have a sentence

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that has more than one meaning.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's syntactically correct and static semantically correct.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But in programming languages, the program

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that you write, the set of instructions that you write,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: only has one meaning.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So remember, we're coming back to the fact

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that the computer only does what you tell it to do.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's not going to suddenly decide

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to add another variable for some reason.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's just going to execute whatever

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: statements you've put up.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in programming languages, there's only one meaning.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But the problem that comes into play

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in programming languages is it's not the meaning

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that you might have intended as the programmer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's where things can go wrong.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And there's going to be a lecture on debugging

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: a little bit later in the course.

chunks.text: But this is here just to tell you

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that if you see an error pop up in your program,

chunks.text: it's just some text that says error.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: For example, if we do something like this.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This is syntactically incorrect.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Incorrect, syntactically incorrect.

chunks.text: See, there's some angry text right here.

chunks.text: But this is basically telling me the line that I wrote

chunks.text: is syntactically incorrect.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it's pointing me to the exact line

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and says this is wrong.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I can go back and fix it as a programmer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So syntax errors are actually really easily

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: caught by Python.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Static semantic errors.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that was an example of a syntax error.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Static semantic errors can also be caught by Python

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: as long as, if your program has some decisions to make,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: as long as you've gone down the branch where

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the static semantic error happens.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this is probably going to be the most frustrating one,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: especially as you're starting out.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The program might do something different

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: than what you expected it to do.

chunks.text: Well, the program didn't suddenly decide to change

chunks.text: It just executed the program that you wrote.

chunks.text: So that's the case where the program gave you

chunks.text: a different answer than expected.

chunks.text: Programs might crash, which means they stop running.

chunks.text: That's OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Just go back to your code and figure out what was wrong.

chunks.text: And another example of different meaning
